You can replace the fans in a Chilipad with Noctua NF-A9s and eliminate the fan noise at night. (There's still pump noise, and you have to be happy reading fan connector pin-outs and soldering wires, but it's a lot quieter. Certainly voids all warranties.)

Related to Rust/LLVMs (non-)support for minor platforms: the global "we" should be more forthright in deciding that some architectural questions are settled. Signed numbers are two's complement. Obvious? Try telling C that! More controversially: little-endian has won.

LA protests on Saturday were very close so I've taken an interest in videos & photos from the day. I also spent a lot of time listening to the police radio during the events, and walked around to see things.

Most of the problems were deliberately caused by the police. (1/10)

There's a crowd of a couple hundred facing off against police at the end of my block. They're occasionally throwing rocks and firing fireworks at the cops. Yet a dozen cars/minute drive right up to it, angry & confused at the idea that they can't drive through the crowd. Very LA.

Crypto-twitter is mad that Zoom is duplicating stuff because of FIPS, but limited algorithm selection is, I find, a more minor cost of FIPS. The â€œintegrityâ€ check, and the eng time spent doing busy-work x times per year for y different platforms is much larger.

@X_Cli_Public @jedisct1 Creating large ciphertexts _can_ be reasonable, and mmap, O_TMPFILE etc might make it more efficient. The worry comes when smaller systems need to process them. What if they don't have enough buffer space, even on disk? Does that push them towards doing dangerous things?

Three+ years and several papers later there's now RFC 8452: AES-GCM-SIV. Want to take advantage of AES-GCM hardware support but dislike AES-GCM exploding if you ever repeat a nonce? Try new AES-GCM-SIV. (Encryption runs at about 75â€“90% of GCM, decryption should be ~same.)

@AaronToponce I consider AES-192 to be a mistake. More options are really expensive because of the combinatorial amplification of total configurations. Against that, AES-192 is insufficient for those who'll want the biggest number and slower than those rationally aiming at a 128-bit sec level.

@fugueish @bascule That _would_ be lovely. I've asked Intel in the past, but they have not done it. I'm not privy to their internal discussions about why, but certainly some people at Intel understand that folks would be upset if they, say, made multiplication vartime. So far, that's worked.

@fugueish @bascule I believe, and measurements show, that the constant-time discipline achieves constant-time behaviour on mainstream CPUs. (There are known wrinkles, like tiny cores w/ vartime mult: https://t.co/Q9SQwxsKdl). Spectre is still an issue, but timing should not be.
